title: The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
author: Carl Sagan
description: A defense of scientific thinking and skepticism that shows how the methods of science and everyday 'baloney detection' protect us from pseudoscience, superstition, and manipulation.

ideas.title: Scientific Method
ideas.description: A systematic way of forming hypotheses, testing them against evidence, and revising them, designed to expose and correct error over time.

ideas.title: Skepticism as a Tool
ideas.description: A habit of withholding belief until claims survive questioning and evidence checks, used to avoid being fooled rather than to dismiss everything.

ideas.title: Pattern-Seeking and Pareidolia
ideas.description: The mind’s tendency to see meaningful patterns and faces in random noise, which explains phenomena like the 'face on Mars' and many false positives.

ideas.title: Extraordinary Claims Principle
ideas.description: The rule that extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence, because the more a claim clashes with established knowledge, the stronger the proof needed.

ideas.title: Aliens and UFO Claims
ideas.description: A case study in how anecdotes, blurry photos, and missing evidence fall short of the standards needed to justify belief in extraterrestrial visitors.

ideas.title: Hallucinations and Perception Limits
ideas.description: The idea that vivid experiences can be generated entirely by the brain, showing why first-person reports alone are not reliable proof of external events.

ideas.title: Science vs Pseudoscience
ideas.description: A distinction based on testability, openness to refutation, and peer criticism versus reliance on anecdotes, ad hoc excuses, and isolation from scrutiny.

ideas.title: Baloney Detection Kit
ideas.description: A practical checklist for evaluating claims, including checking sources, seeking independent confirmation, using Occam’s razor, and looking for falsification tests.

ideas.title: Falsifiability and Burden of Proof
ideas.description: The idea that meaningful claims must expose themselves to possible disproof, and that the claimant—not the skeptic—bears the burden of providing evidence.

ideas.title: Unfalsifiable Claims
ideas.description: Claims like the 'invisible dragon in my garage' that are protected from any possible test, making them scientifically empty even if emotionally compelling.

ideas.title: Pseudoscience Tactics
ideas.description: Common moves such as cherry-picking data, moving goalposts, attacking critics, and invoking conspiracy to explain away failures instead of revising the claim.

ideas.title: Evidence-Based Medicine
ideas.description: The view that treatments—whether conventional or 'alternative'—must be judged by controlled trials and data, not by tradition or testimonials alone.

ideas.title: Superstition and Moral Panics
ideas.description: How fear plus ignorance of natural causes can lead to witch hunts and persecutions, showing the social cost of demon-haunted thinking.

ideas.title: Science and Moral Responsibility
ideas.description: The idea that although knowledge itself is neutral, scientists and citizens share responsibility for how technologies—from nukes to biotech—are developed and used.

ideas.title: Curiosity and No Dumb Questions
ideas.description: A cultural norm that questions should be welcomed, not punished, especially in children, because curiosity is the engine of scientific progress.

ideas.title: Skeptical Citizenship
ideas.description: Applying the same critical habits used in science to politics, media, and advertising, so that citizens are harder to manipulate by propaganda or spin.

ideas.title: Skepticism and Wonder Together
ideas.description: The stance that rigorous doubt and childlike awe are compatible: understanding more about reality deepens wonder instead of killing it.

title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
author: Daniel Kahneman
description: A tour of how fast, intuitive System 1 and slow, deliberate System 2 shape our judgments and choices, and how their interaction leads to systematic biases in decision-making and memory.

ideas.title: System 1 and System 2
ideas.description: Two interacting modes of thinking: fast, automatic, intuitive System 1 and slow, deliberate, effortful System 2, with System 2 often endorsing System 1’s quick impressions.

ideas.title: Attention and Effort
ideas.description: System 2 requires limited mental energy and focused attention, so when tasks are demanding, people are more likely to default to shortcuts from System 1.

ideas.title: Lazy System 2
ideas.description: System 2 tends to conserve effort and usually accepts System 1’s suggestions unless there is a clear reason to intervene, making bias correction rare by default.

ideas.title: Associative Machine
ideas.description: System 1 constantly links ideas, emotions, and memories into coherent stories, so subtle primes—words, images, or moods—can shift judgments without our awareness.

ideas.title: Cognitive Ease
ideas.description: Information that feels familiar and easy to process is judged as more true and safe, while effortful processing creates doubt and can trigger more careful thinking.

ideas.title: Norms and Causes
ideas.description: System 1 quickly classifies events as normal or surprising and invents simple causal stories, often underplaying randomness and complexity.

ideas.title: What You See Is All There Is
ideas.description: System 1 acts on the information that is salient and available, ignoring what is missing, so we build confident stories from incomplete data instead of seeking further evidence.

ideas.title: Question Substitution
ideas.description: When asked a hard question, the mind often unconsciously substitutes an easier one—such as 'How do I feel about this?'—and answers that instead.

ideas.title: Law of Small Numbers
ideas.description: People expect small samples to faithfully represent the population, so they overinterpret streaks and anomalies that are mostly just statistical noise.

ideas.title: Anchoring
ideas.description: Initial numbers, even if arbitrary, pull subsequent judgments toward them, biasing estimates in negotiations, pricing, and forecasting.

ideas.title: Availability Heuristic
ideas.description: Judgments of frequency and risk are driven by how easily examples come to mind, so vivid or recent events feel more common than they really are.

ideas.title: Representativeness Heuristic
ideas.description: People judge probabilities by similarity to stereotypes, leading to neglect of base rates and misunderstanding of randomness.

ideas.title: Conjunction Fallacy
ideas.description: Because detailed stories feel more representative, people often judge a specific scenario as more likely than a broader one that logically includes it.

ideas.title: Regression to the Mean
ideas.description: Extreme performances or outcomes tend to be followed by more average ones, but people mistakenly attribute this to interventions instead of statistics.

ideas.title: Illusion of Validity
ideas.description: Confidence in a judgment is driven by the coherence of the story, not actual accuracy, so experts often feel sure even when their predictions are poor.

ideas.title: Hindsight and Narrative Fallacy
ideas.description: In hindsight, people weave narratives that make events seem predictable and inevitable, reinforcing overconfidence in their ability to foresee complex outcomes.

ideas.title: Planning Fallacy
ideas.description: Individuals and organizations underestimate time, cost, and risks by focusing on optimistic inside views instead of using outside statistical baselines.

ideas.title: Prospect Theory
ideas.description: A model of decision-making in which outcomes are evaluated as gains or losses relative to a reference point, with diminishing sensitivity and loss aversion shaping choices.

ideas.title: Reference Points
ideas.description: People evaluate outcomes relative to a changing baseline—such as current wealth or expectations—rather than in absolute terms.

ideas.title: Loss Aversion
ideas.description: Losses loom larger than equivalent gains, making people risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking when trying to avoid losses.

ideas.title: Endowment Effect and Status Quo Bias
ideas.description: People value what they already own more than identical items they do not, and they overweight the disadvantages of change, leading to inertia.

ideas.title: Framing Effects
ideas.description: Logically equivalent descriptions—such as survival rates versus mortality rates—can lead to different preferences, because choices depend on whether options are framed as gains or losses.

ideas.title: Mental Accounting
ideas.description: People mentally partition money and outcomes into separate 'accounts' and evaluate decisions locally, often leading to globally inconsistent choices.

ideas.title: Probability Weighting and Rare Events
ideas.description: People overweight small probabilities and underweight moderate and high ones, helping explain behaviors like buying both lottery tickets and insurance.

ideas.title: Experiencing vs Remembering Self
ideas.description: The experiencing self lives in the present moment, while the remembering self constructs stories about episodes and largely determines future choices.

ideas.title: Peak-End Rule and Duration Neglect
ideas.description: Memory of an experience depends mostly on its most intense moment and how it ended, with duration playing little role in the remembered evaluation.

ideas.title: Focusing Illusion
ideas.description: When thinking about one aspect of life—like income or location—people temporarily exaggerate its impact on happiness, forgetting that many other factors matter too.

title: The Selfish Gene
author: Richard Dawkins
description: An explanation of evolution from the perspective of genes as replicators, showing how gene-level selection can produce cooperation, altruism, conflict, and cultural evolution.

ideas.title: Gene-Centred View
ideas.description: Natural selection is best understood at the level of genes, which persist across generations while organisms are temporary vehicles that genes build.

ideas.title: Replicators and Survival Machines
ideas.description: Early evolution involved self-copying molecules—replicators—that later built protective 'survival machines' (organisms) to improve their replication chances.

ideas.title: Selfish Gene Metaphor
ideas.description: Calling genes 'selfish' means that genes which promote their own replication spread, even if the behaviors they produce look cooperative or altruistic at the organism level.

ideas.title: Gene vs Group Selection
ideas.description: Many phenomena that look like group-level selection can be explained more cleanly by genes promoting strategies that help copies of themselves, without invoking sacrifice for the group as a whole.

ideas.title: Altruism as Genetic Strategy
ideas.description: Apparent altruism—helping others at a cost to oneself—can evolve when the beneficiaries carry copies of the same genes, turning self-sacrifice into indirect genetic self-interest.

ideas.title: Inclusive Fitness
ideas.description: An individual’s genetic success includes not only its own reproduction but also the reproduction of relatives who share its genes, broadening what 'fitness' means.

ideas.title: Hamilton’s Rule
ideas.description: A gene for altruism spreads when the cost to the helper is less than the benefit to the recipient multiplied by their genetic relatedness (C < r × B).

ideas.title: Kin Selection
ideas.description: Selection favoring behaviors that help genetic relatives explains patterns like worker ants helping their queen or animals risking themselves for siblings.

ideas.title: Evolutionarily Stable Strategy
ideas.description: An evolutionarily stable strategy (ESS) is a behavioral strategy that, once common, cannot be invaded by alternatives, providing a game-theoretic tool for analyzing social behavior.

ideas.title: Hawk-Dove Model
ideas.description: A simple game where aggressive 'hawks' and peaceful 'doves' interact shows how mixes of strategies can be stable, depending on the costs and benefits of fighting.

ideas.title: Reciprocal Altruism
ideas.description: Helping unrelated individuals can evolve when interactions are repeated and aid is likely to be repaid, making cooperation a long-run beneficial strategy.

ideas.title: Tit-for-Tat Strategy
ideas.description: In repeated interactions, a simple rule—cooperate on the first move, then copy your partner’s last move—can be an effective and stable strategy for reciprocal altruism.

ideas.title: Parent-Offspring Conflict
ideas.description: Parents and offspring share genes but not all of them, creating conflicts over resources like weaning time because each has slightly different genetic interests.

ideas.title: Sibling Rivalry
ideas.description: Siblings may compete for parental investment because each is more related to itself than to its siblings, though shared genes can also promote cooperation when it benefits them all.

ideas.title: Sexual Selection
ideas.description: Differences in parental investment between males and females drive traits like competition among males and choosiness among females, shaping elaborate displays and behaviors.

ideas.title: Sex Ratios and Strategy
ideas.description: Genes can spread by influencing the proportion of sons and daughters produced when certain sex ratios yield higher expected genetic payoff.

ideas.title: Extended Phenotype
ideas.description: A gene’s effects can extend beyond the body—into structures like beaver dams or manipulated host behavior—so these external effects are also part of what selection acts on.

ideas.title: Memes as Cultural Replicators
ideas.description: Memes—ideas, tunes, and practices—replicate by spreading between minds, undergoing selection pressures analogous to those acting on genes.

ideas.title: Misreading the Metaphor
ideas.description: Understanding that genes are 'selfish' is a descriptive model, not a moral prescription, and does not justify selfish behavior in human ethics.

ideas.title: Gene-Level Thinking Tool
ideas.description: Thinking in terms of gene interests helps clarify puzzles in behavior, cooperation, and design that are harder to explain with organism- or group-centred views alone.

title: The Beginning of Infinity: Explanations that Transform the World
author: David Deutsch
description: A philosophy of knowledge and progress arguing that good explanations, open-ended criticism, and human creativity can lead to unbounded scientific, technological, and moral improvement.

ideas.title: Reach of Explanations
ideas.description: Explanations are accounts of how the world works that apply far beyond the specific observations that first suggested them, giving them wide reach.

ideas.title: Good vs Bad Explanations
ideas.description: Good explanations are hard to vary while still explaining the same facts, whereas bad ones can be easily adjusted to fit any outcome and therefore explain little.

ideas.title: Fallibilism
ideas.description: All knowledge is conjectural and subject to error, so progress depends on exposing ideas to criticism and improvement rather than seeking certainty or justification.

ideas.title: Problem-Solving View
ideas.description: Knowledge grows through a cycle of proposing solutions to problems, criticizing them, and correcting errors, not through passive observation or induction from data alone.

ideas.title: Reality of Abstractions
ideas.description: Abstract entities like numbers, software, and scientific laws are real in the sense that they have causal and explanatory roles that cannot be reduced to individual physical instances.

ideas.title: Jumps to Universality
ideas.description: Some systems—like universal computers—reach a point where they can emulate any process of a given kind, making further improvements matters of efficiency rather than kind.

ideas.title: Universal Computers and Constructors
ideas.description: Given the right knowledge and resources, universal computers and constructors can carry out any physically allowed computation or transformation.

ideas.title: People as Universal Explainers
ideas.description: Humans are unique in being able to create explanations of arbitrary depth and scope, making them universal explainers whose only limits are knowledge and creativity.

ideas.title: Creativity over Induction
ideas.description: New ideas are not mechanically derived from data; they are creative conjectures that are then tested, so inductive rules cannot replace imaginative explanation.

ideas.title: Beginning of Infinity
ideas.description: If knowledge creation is open-ended, then any stage of progress is just the beginning of an unlimited sequence of further improvements in understanding and capability.

ideas.title: Optimism about Problems
ideas.description: Problems are inevitable but solvable in principle, so rational optimism treats difficulties as prompts for knowledge-creation rather than signs of ultimate limits.

ideas.title: Multiverse Interpretation
ideas.description: Quantum theory is best understood as describing a multiverse of branching histories, which explains interference and probability more naturally than single-universe views.

ideas.title: Anthropic Reasoning
ideas.description: Anthropic explanations—appealing to the conditions needed for observers to exist—are legitimate only when embedded in detailed, testable physical theories.

ideas.title: Static vs Dynamic Societies
ideas.description: Static societies seek to freeze traditions and suppress new ideas, while dynamic societies institutionalize criticism and change, enabling unbounded progress.

ideas.title: Rational and Anti-Rational Memes
ideas.description: Cultural ideas can either encourage criticism and improvement or suppress them; anti-rational memes spread by blocking criticism rather than by being true.

ideas.title: Moral Knowledge as Explanatory
ideas.description: Moral truths, if they exist, are discovered and improved through the same process of conjecture and criticism as scientific truths, not by authority or revelation.

ideas.title: Unsustainability as Knowledge Problem
ideas.description: Resource and environmental limits are ultimately problems of inadequate knowledge about how to use resources better, not fixed ceilings on progress.

ideas.title: Beauty as Guide to Truth
ideas.description: Aesthetic judgments in science—like elegance and simplicity—often correlate with deeper, more unified explanations, though they remain fallible guides.

ideas.title: Error-Correcting Institutions
ideas.description: Good political and social institutions are those that make it easy to detect and correct errors through criticism, free speech, and checks and balances.

ideas.title: Explanation over Prediction
ideas.description: Predictive success alone is not enough; theories must also explain why things happen, because shallow curve-fitting without explanation is fragile.

ideas.title: Universality of Reason
ideas.description: Any universal explainer can in principle understand the explanations of any other, so reason is not confined to one culture or species.

ideas.title: Open-Ended Progress
ideas.description: As long as we preserve traditions of criticism and creativity, we can expect unending improvement in science, technology, and morality, with each solved problem revealing better new problems.

title: Antifragile: Things That Gain from Disorder
author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
description: A framework for understanding systems that benefit from volatility, randomness, and stress, and for designing lives, portfolios, and institutions that gain from disorder.

ideas.title: Fragile Robust Antifragile
ideas.description: Fragile things are harmed by volatility, robust things resist it, and antifragile things actually benefit from shocks and variability.

ideas.title: Nonlinearity and Convexity
ideas.description: When responses to stressors are nonlinear, small shocks can help while large ones harm, and convex payoff structures—limited downside with large upside—create antifragility to randomness.

ideas.title: Hormesis and Overcompensation
ideas.description: Biological and social systems often overcompensate to small stressors—like muscles growing stronger after being stressed—illustrating hormesis when stress is applied in the right dose.

ideas.title: Randomness as Information
ideas.description: Noise and volatility reveal hidden fragilities and help robust and antifragile strategies outcompete fragile ones, so randomness is a source of information, not just a nuisance.

ideas.title: Turkey Problem
ideas.description: Apparent stability—like a turkey being fed every day—can hide growing fragility, so rare, extreme events can abruptly destroy systems that looked safe based on past data.

ideas.title: Redundancy as Insurance
ideas.description: Redundancy—extra reserves, slack, and backup systems—is a feature, not a bug, because it allows systems to survive and benefit from shocks that would destroy optimized, lean designs.

ideas.title: Barbell Strategy
ideas.description: A barbell approach combines extreme safety on one side with small, speculative bets on the other, avoiding medium risk and creating overall antifragility to shocks and errors in forecasting.

ideas.title: Optionality
ideas.description: Having many options with limited downside and open-ended upside lets you benefit from randomness without needing accurate predictions about specific events.

ideas.title: Trial and Error
ideas.description: Systematic trial-and-error with small, reversible bets is a powerful way to discover antifragile opportunities in uncertain domains.

ideas.title: Non-Predictive Decisions
ideas.description: Taleb advocates judging decisions by their exposure to harm or benefit—via payoff profiles—rather than by whether predictions come true.

ideas.title: Iatrogenics
ideas.description: Interventions, especially in medicine and policy, can cause more harm than the problem itself, so sometimes the antifragile choice is to do less or nothing.

ideas.title: Naive Interventionism
ideas.description: Taleb calls 'fragilistas' those who add complex interventions and controls without understanding their limits, often increasing hidden fragility while claiming to stabilize systems.

ideas.title: Hidden Fragility in Complexity
ideas.description: Layered financial instruments, overengineered technologies, and opaque regulations can hide fragility, making simple and transparent structures safer.

ideas.title: Scale and Small Units
ideas.description: Smaller units—city-states, local businesses, modular components—are often more antifragile because failures are contained, while large, tightly coupled systems suffer from cascading breakdowns.

ideas.title: Decentralization and Local Knowledge
ideas.description: Decentralized, bottom-up decision-making harnesses local knowledge and allows parallel experimentation, while centralized control magnifies errors and fragility.

ideas.title: Lindy Effect
ideas.description: For non-perishable things like books or technologies, the longer they have survived, the longer they are expected to survive, making 'time-tested' options often more robust.

ideas.title: Via Negativa
ideas.description: Removing sources of fragility—like debt, excess complexity, or toxic habits—is often more effective than adding new interventions, because what is absent cannot harm you.

ideas.title: Skin in the Game
ideas.description: Systems become fragile when decision-makers do not bear the consequences of their errors, so requiring 'skin in the game' aligns incentives and filters out harmful strategies over time.

ideas.title: Ethics of Skin in the Game
ideas.description: Ethically, no one should be able to expose others to large risks without bearing comparable risks themselves, making 'skin in the game' a moral principle, not just a heuristic.

ideas.title: Green Lumber Problem
ideas.description: Success in complex domains often comes from exploiting payoff structures rather than fully understanding causal stories, as in traders who profit from patterns they cannot explain well.

ideas.title: Antifragile Careers
ideas.description: Designing a career with multiple options, low fixed costs, and small experiments creates antifragility, whereas single-track, high-commitment paths are fragile to shocks.

ideas.title: Stoic Practices
ideas.description: Stoic habits—like rehearsing worst cases and lowering dependence on externals—can make people emotionally antifragile by turning setbacks into training rather than trauma.

ideas.title: Barbells in Life and Innovation
ideas.description: The barbell pattern—extreme safety plus small, risky bets—applies beyond finance to innovation, career, and personal projects, protecting the downside while keeping upside open.

ideas.title: Designing Antifragile Systems
ideas.description: We can deliberately design systems to benefit from disorder by combining convex payoffs, redundancy, decentralization, skin in the game, and via negativa.
